text:
<@UUN8GHQ4R> I think this should be of help: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/developer-reference/local-development-cms-cli#modes>

You need to set `--overwrite` `--mode=publish`

Can you verify you are uploading to the correct portal? an easy accident  is to upload to the wrong `defaultPortal`

Another thing to be aware of, the design manager UI does not instantly know your files have changed or have been uploaded, so you may need to refresh.
I only have one portal, so yep, it should be uploading to the same portal.
Thanks for the answer <@U54TVT3C1>, How about watch? There’s no --overwrite parameter and it wasn’t watching for my files.
Sorry, I think you only need to add `--mode=publish` to watch.  Someone more knowledgeable than me care to chime in?
can you DM me a log of your terminal, and copy n paste the contents of the HubSpot.config.yml file with any API keys, access keys, obfuscated? (Portal id’s are fine to leave in)
These docs are definitively getting better: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/tutorials/getting-started-with-modules>

i think for teams that the best way to work is for each developer to have their own sandbox that they use day-to-day. if you don’t go that route, developers end up stepping on each others toes.

there has been a pretty good number of people all working on the code for <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs> and <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs-beta> which are in different portals. we have been using sandboxes in combination with `scripts` in package.json (like `start` and `deploy`) and instructions in a README. there are times where it is a little awkward like when you need some particular content to test like menus.

one thing that we also have done is have a `style-guide.html` template that is marked `isAvailableForNewContent: false` that has all the modules in the theme. we can then use that to check that modules are working as expected.
